nodes.bodyText: add a new bool param called fast, if its fast you can use the fast allocator, otherwise the slow one.

no _sp in this context, need to return a value with JIT_RETURN_UDATA(obj);
dont think this helper is needed, you have just put the code in here
this will have to be added to a function table, same as the other one. you can rename them to [load/store]FlattenableArrayElement

nodes.bodyText: you need the index as well
should  be using the VT helper here as well, with fast = FALSE
this can be moved above the done: label so you dont need the !slowPathUsed
why is this moved?
i dont think you need the slow version
indenting needs to be fixed, make sure you are using tabs not spaces
same thing here with the indenting
if you are doing an out-of-line allocation youll need to build a special frame in case of a GC
Could you take a look at what I've got down now to make sure it's correct?
need frame build before setting the exception
same here, and below
extra line here
that boolean fast wont compile on windows, use fast != false instead
instead of pushing frame here, just make sure caller pushes frame if fast is set to false. You can add something in the comments
this else branch is not needed, all the checks are done before calling this function
fast should be checked here, if fast use _objectAllocate.inlineAllocateObject else use currentThread->javaVM->memoryManagerFunctions->J9AllocateObject
add javadocs here as well
rename to store/loadFlattenableArrayElement
these functions should be used in the bytecodeinterpreter so we dont duplicate logic
To confirm, I should replace the code currently in ByteCodeInterpreter with these functions?
yes
Should I add that it assumes the index is less than the array size and that it does not throw exceptions?
yes
you can add that all AIOB exceptions must be thrown before hand
This line will then go to JIT_RETURN_UDATA(value), returning NULL. I want to confirm that this is fine?
if you are throwing an exception you dont need to set the return val, you can just jum straight to done
or conversely, just move up the JIT_RETURN_UDATA(value); to after the NULL check for the return value
fast == false, so I need to build a special frame. Is this the correct way to do it in this context, or should I use OutOfLineNL?
the frame should be built before call the function
So I build it regardless of the path being fast or slow?
it should only be built on a slow path
look at old_slow_jitGetFlattenableField for an example
you dont need that comment

you dont need to pass the address, you just need to do a re-interpret cast.
ie. currentThread->floatTemp2 = *(void **)&index
same here with the re-intepret cast
you dont need to push/pop arrayObject in a special frame
why is this being done?
This is what is done on the ByteCodeInterpreter version of aaload  if the index is greater than the array length. Let me know if you think it is not needed.
In the interpreter we have a special routine that will look at the tempSlot so that it can print a more helpful exception message. We dont have that here.
you need to add currentThread->floatTemp1 = (void*)valuet; // in case of decompile before restore the jit frame
also do the value null check before restore the jit frame so you dont need to build another frame to set the exception
where is the jitStoreFlattenableArrayElement helper?
you dont need the J9_IS_J9CLASS_FLATTENED check here

Removing the J9_IS_J9CLASS_FLATTENED will cause a system dump. I believe the reason is value = _objectAccessBarrier.inlineIndexableObjectReadObject(currentThread, receiverObject, index); is being run in all cases in which the value is not flattened. In the case that it does return null it will always hit the HEAP_OOM error (which should occur only if the slow path is used and returns null, not the non flattened path returns null) This was the simplest way I could come up with to prevent that.
yo can just reuse value
add brackets (NULL == value)
you dont need the vt check here

nodes.bodyText: no need for ifdefs in the jitruntime helpers since they are only called when VTs are enabled
same here
this test is not needed, the helper will only be called if the array is a valuetype

you dont need to copy this function, I didnt realize this is what you were talking about. Yes, your original suggestion of moving this into VMHelpers.hpp is correct. This way it can be shared by the interpreter and the runtime helpres
its not actually possible to get here, you can only be in the slow path if you are throwing an exception, since the storing the element cant fail
add a comment saying "We only get here due to an allocation failure"
need to push/pop receiverObject in special frame as J9AllocateObject might cause GC

It's stated in the function's comment

"If fast == false, special stack frame must be built and receiverObject must be pushed onto it."
Let me know if you'd still like me to change it.
ah forgot about that. ignore that comment
can you delete the existing one in the bytecode interpreter
since this code has to throw, you can just build once the frame upfront
This is the problem, J9_IS_J9CLASS_VALUETYPE(arrayrefClass), arrayclasses are never marked as VT's only the element types. This should remain as the J9_IS_J9CLASS_FLATTENED test
